byline.original: By KIMBERLY STEPHENS and JOANNE RUTHSATZ

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama said the success of his initiative to collect genetic data so scientists can develop drugs and personalized treatments hinged partly on “understanding who owns the data.”

headline.main: President Weighs In on Data From Genes
headline.print_headline: President Weighs In on Data From Genes

docs.abstract: Pres Obama says during forum on his administration's Precision Medicine Initiative that he believes any discoveries made using person's genetic information should belong to owner of DNA used; initiative seeks to collect genetic data from one million volunteers, and Obama says success relies in part on determining who owns data; many researchers backed by universities and medical center regard genetic material and test results as intellectual property they are not compelled to share.
docs.snippet: President Obama said the success of his initiative to collect genetic data so scientists can develop drugs and personalized treatments hinged partly on “understanding who owns the data.”

docs.lead_paragraph: Often drowned out by the dire warnings and fear surrounding Zika, some medical professionals are saying that Brazil and international health officials have prematurely declared a link between the virus and what appears to be a surge in birth defects.

headline.main: Some Experts Contend Brazil Is Exaggerating Zika Crisis
headline.print_headline: Some Experts Contend Brazil Is Exaggerating Zika Crisis

docs.snippet: Often drowned out by the dire warnings and fear surrounding Zika, some medical professionals are saying that Brazil and international health officials have prematurely declared a link between the virus and what appears to be a surge in birth defects.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama held out the promise of medical breakthroughs Thursday as his administration moved ahead with a major project to learn how to better tailor treatments and preventive care to people's genes, environment and lifestyle.

headline.main: NIH Taking First Steps on Huge Precision Medicine Project
headline.print_headline: NIH Taking First Steps on Huge Precision Medicine Project

docs.snippet: President Barack Obama held out the promise of medical breakthroughs Thursday as his administration moved ahead with a major project to learn how to better tailor treatments and preventive care to people's genes, environment and lifestyle.

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Institutes of Health on Thursday named Verily, formerly Google Life Sciences, as adviser to Nashville's Vanderbilt University in a pilot program to launch the Precision Medicine Initiative outlined by President Barack Obama last year.

headline.main: Verily, Vanderbilt to Test Enrollment in U.S. Precision Medicine Pilot
headline.print_headline: Verily, Vanderbilt to Test Enrollment in U.S. Precision Medicine Pilot

docs.snippet: The National Institutes of Health on Thursday named Verily, formerly Google Life Sciences, as adviser to Nashville's Vanderbilt University in a pilot program to launch the Precision Medicine Initiative outlined by President Barack Obama last year.

docs.lead_paragraph: Evidence is building for the theory that Zika can cause newborn brain defects and the World Health Organization is promising more answers in weeks, but nailing a definitive link will be neither simple nor swift.

headline.main: Insight: Proving Zika Guilty-A Long and Painstaking Task
headline.print_headline: Insight: Proving Zika Guilty-A Long and Painstaking Task

docs.snippet: Evidence is building for the theory that Zika can cause newborn brain defects and the World Health Organization is promising more answers in weeks, but nailing a definitive link will be neither simple nor swift.

docs.lead_paragraph: The agency said it was investigating new cases of transmission from male travelers to female partners and had confirmed two of them.

headline.main: C.D.C. Investigating 14 New Reports of Zika Transmission Through Sex
headline.print_headline: 14 New Reports of Sexual Transmission of Zika in U.S.

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is investigating 14 reports of sexual transmission of Zika virus, including to pregnant women; cases, if confirmed, would have major implications for controlling virus thought to be mainly spread by mosquito bites.
docs.snippet: The agency said it was investigating new cases of transmission from male travelers to female partners and had confirmed two of them.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: In a new approach to HIV prevention, women modestly reduced their risk of infection by inserting a vaginal ring coated with an anti-AIDS drug once a month, according to two long-awaited studies from Africa.

headline.main: Study Finds Anti-AIDS Vaginal Ring Partially Protects Women
headline.print_headline: Study Finds Anti-AIDS Vaginal Ring Partially Protects Women

docs.snippet: In a new approach to HIV prevention, women modestly reduced their risk of infection by inserting a vaginal ring coated with an anti-AIDS drug once a month, according to two long-awaited studies from Africa.

docs.abstract: I’m both a clinician and a historian of my field. It’s not as easy as it sounds.
docs.snippet: I’m both a clinician and a historian of my field. It’s not as easy as it sounds.

docs.lead_paragraph: A flexible ring that slowly releases an antiviral drug into the vagina helped protect African women against H.I.V. infection, two studies reported.

headline.main: Vaginal Ring With Drug Lowers H.I.V. Rates in African Women
headline.print_headline: Vaginal Ring Helps to Protect African Women From H.I.V.

docs.abstract: Studies show cheap silicone vaginal ring helped prevent African women from contracting HIV; device releases antiviral drug, lasts for 5 years and gives woman total control over its use; researchers see news as major breakthrough and seek ring's wide distribution, while HIV-prevention advocates are more cautiously optimistic.
docs.snippet: A flexible ring that slowly releases an antiviral drug into the vagina helped protect African women against H.I.V. infection, two studies reported.
